sections.title: Introduction
body: A linked list is a linear data structure in which elements are stored in nodes, and each node contains data along with a pointer/reference to the next node.
Unlike arrays, linked lists do not store elements in contiguous memory locations. The nodes can be scattered anywhere in memory.
The first node is called the head, and the last node points to NULL (in singly linked list).
Linked lists support dynamic memory allocation, meaning their size can grow or shrink at runtime without needing to shift elements.
They are useful when frequent insertions and deletions are required, especially in the middle of the list.
Different types of linked lists include Singly Linked List, Doubly Linked List, Circular Linked List, and Doubly Circular Linked List.

sections.title: Types of Linked Lists
body: Singly Linked List: Each node contains data and a pointer to the next node.
Doubly Linked List: Each node contains data, a pointer to the next node, and a pointer to the previous node.
Circular Linked List: The last node points back to the first node instead of pointing to NULL.
Doubly Circular Linked List: A combination of doubly and circular lists where last node points to first and first node points to last.

sections.title: Advantages
body: Dynamic size: Can grow or shrink during runtime.
Efficient insertions/deletions: No need to shift elements like in arrays.
Memory utilization: Memory allocated only when needed.
Flexibility: Useful for implementing stacks, queues, graphs, and adjacency lists.

sections.title: Disadvantages
body: No random access: Cannot directly access an element using index (unlike arrays).
Extra memory: Each node requires extra space for storing pointers.
Slower traversal: Must start from the head to reach any node.
Difficult to implement: More complex than arrays due to pointer handling.

sections.title: Time Complexity
body: Access: O(n) — Because elements must be traversed from the head to the required index.
Search: O(n) — Each node is checked one by one.
Insert at Beginning: O(1) — Only pointer update is required.
Insert at End: O(n) — Need to traverse up to the last node.
Insert at Middle: O(n) — Must traverse to the correct position.
Delete at Beginning: O(1) — Head pointer is updated.
Delete at End: O(n) — Need to traverse to the second-last node.
Delete at Middle: O(n) — Must traverse to the correct position before deletion.

sections.title: Applications
body: Used in implementing dynamic data structures like stacks and queues.
Used in adjacency lists for graph representation.
Used in memory management and operating system scheduling.
Used in undo/redo operations (doubly linked list).
Used in music playlists, image slideshow (circular linked list).
